title: Step details in AFL flows
content:
The Step Inspector pane allows you to view and edit information about steps and transitions from an AFL flow.

Note: Editing is only available for AFL flows from the Projects pane. The Dependencies pane flows remain read-only.

Open step details in Step Inspector

Select a step from any AFL flow, then click the Inspector tab at the bottom of the AFL canvas to expand or collapse the pane.

The Step Inspector for steps allows you to view and edit data in the following tabs:

Tab Description
Inputs The Inputs tab displays the step inputs. Selecting a step input will populate the Inputs details pane on the right. 
Results The Results tab displays the outputs defined for a particular step.
Display The Display tab shows if a prompt will display before this particular step is executed. If you enable this option, the information about the title of the prompt, prompt sizes, and prompt text will display in the corresponding boxes.
Description The Description tab shows the step description.
Advanced The Advanced tab shows the options chosen for Step Persistence (Detailed or Concise), the Execution details, and settings regarding Rerun point and Throttle parallel execution, the latter being displayed for multi-instance steps. It also displays operation-specific information such as Link to, which shows the actual name of the operation used and the Location of the operation displayed as a path. 
Scriptlet  The Scriptlet tab contains a script editor that displays the formatted JavaScript code added for that step. 

The GUI items of each tab are detailed below: 

Inputs tab GUI items

GUI item Description
NAME Enter the name for the new input.
SENSITIVE DATA Mark the input as sensitive data.
REQUIRED To make the input mandatory for the step to function, select the Required check box.
TYPE

From the Type list, specify how the input gets its value:

  • Single value 
  • List of values: This enables you to run an operation with an input that contains multiple values.
ASSIGN FROM

Specify the input source in the Input Inspector:

  • To assign the value from a variable with the same name as the input, select the default name (marked by the prefix <default>) that appears at the top of the Assign From list.

  • To assign the value from a different flow variable, select the variable name in the Assign From list.

  • If you don't want to define a source for this input, select <not assigned> in the Assign From list.
OTHERWISE

In the Otherwise list, you select the action to occur if the flow variable that you specified in the Assign from box doesn't exist or has no value stored in it. When you click on an input name, the right pane is automatically updated with its details. Fill in the fields in the right pane by choosing from the following options:

  • Use Constant: Enter the constant value that will be used for the input. For example, an IP address that's always used.

  • Prompt User: Set up a prompt for the user to supply the information, either by entering information or making a selection from a list, at the start of the flow.

    • Prompt For: Text - Prompt the user to enter information. Type the prompt that the user will see in the User Message box. For example, Enter a value for eventid.

    • Prompt For: Selection - Prompt the user to select a value. Select the type of list the user will select from:

      Selection List: Choose the selection list from the Named list. All the selection lists are shown.

      Domain Term: Select the domain term from the Named list. All the domain terms are shown.

      Flow Variable: Select the name of a flow variable. Flow variables are defined in the results for flows. Type a delimiter for the flow variables in the Source Delimiter field.

It's not recommended to use the Prompt User option for a step in the middle of a flow.

  • Use Previous Step Result: Select a previous step result to be used if the Assign From variable for the input doesn't exist or has no value.

    For example, you might have a first step that looks for a piece of information that requires the user to enter text and saves this information as a flow variable. Then, you might have a second step that displays that information. The second step uses the flow variable that was created in the first step.

  • System Account: Select the system account name and credential type.
  • Logged-in User Credentials: Select the credential type of the logged-in user.

The System Account and Logged-in User Credentials fields don't appear if you define the input as a List of Values in the Type field.

When you create a new input for an operation, flow, or step, the default value for Otherwise is automatically set to Use Constant.
ASSIGN TO

Specify the input target in the Input Editor:

  • To assign the value to a variable with the same name as the input, select the default name (marked by the prefix <default>) that appears at the top of the Assign To list.

  • To assign the value to a different flow variable, select the variable name in the Assign To list.

  • If you don't want to define a target for this input, select <not assigned> in the Assign To list.

Results tab GUI items

GUI item Description
NAME Enter a name for the result. This name will be used as the name of the flow variable or flow output field.
SENSITIVE DATA Make this result hidden in the Central user interface. The result will be displayed as asterisks and won't be persisted in the Operations Orchestration database.
FROM  Select the source for the result.
ASSIGN TO

Select where the result value will be stored:

  • To store the value in a flow variable, select Flow Variable
  • To make the value available to a parent flow, select Flow Output Field
ASSIGNMENT ACTION

From the Assignment Action list, select the appropriate action:

  • OVERWRITE–Replace the current value of the flow variable or flow output field with this value.

  • APPEND–Place this value at the end of the current value of the flow variable or flow output field.

  • PREPEND–Place this value in front of the current value of the flow variable or flow output field.

  • Use the arithmetic assignment actions ADD, SUB, MULTIPLY, and DIVIDE to modify the current value of the flow variable or flow output field.

    For example, if the step result is 3.14, and you select MULTIPLY, the effect is to multiply the current value of the flow variable or flow output field by 3.14.
FILTERS Filter results.

Display tab

The Display tab shows if a prompt will display before this particular step is executed. If you click the Always prompt the user before executing this step check box, the information about the prompt title, prompt sizes, and prompt text will display in the corresponding boxes. 

Description tab

The Description tab shows the step description.

Advanced tab GUI items

GUI item Description
Step Persistence
Detailed Presents detailed information when running the flow including step ID, start/end time, and step inputs and results. This information may be useful when troubleshooting the flow.
Concise Presents basic information when running the flow including step ID and start/end time.

Use this option when you want to reduce the amount of data persisted in the database and you don't need to troubleshoot the specific step.
Execution
Rerun point Marks the step as a rerun point. If a step is defined as a rerun point, you can rerun the flow from this step in Central without having to rerun the entire flow. This is useful when trying to recover failed flows.

The Rerun option is only available in Central if the administrator has marked the Enable the rerun option for failed/canceled runs check box in System Configuration > System Settings.

The Rerun option is only available in Central for flows that have failed or were canceled.

It's recommended to consider which steps you want to mark as rerun points. Only mark steps from which it's safe and logical to rerun the flow.

Marking a large number of steps as rerun points means that more data is persisted in the database. As a result, some users may experience slower performance during the flow execution

The following point types can't be defined as rerun points:

  • endpoints

  • non-blocking steps

  • steps inside a multi-instance step

  • steps inside parallel steps
Throttle parallel execution Enables throttling parallel execution to a certain number of concurrent instances for multi-instance steps.
Operation
Link to Displays the source operation that the step is based on.
Location Displays the location of the source operation that the step is based on.

Scriptlet tab

From the Type list, select the JavaScript language in which you will write your script: Nashorn (recommended) or Rhino.

  1. Click Insert Template.
  2. Follow the guidelines in the template to write your script.
  3. Click Check Script to validate your script.

View transition details in Step Inspector

Double-click a transition from a flow and the Transition Inspector opens displaying the details of the transition.

GUI item Description
Transition Name Displays the transition name.
Required Role Alias Displays the role alias that the user must be assigned to continue running the flow.
Hand off flow run after this transition Describes whether or not to hand off the flow to another person after the transition.
Transition ROI Value Indicates the Return On Investment value that was set for that particular transition.
Description Displays the description set for the transition.

View parallel step details in Step Inspector

The Step Inspector for parallel steps displays four tabs containing read-only information: Inputs, Description, Advanced, and Scriptlet.
